Another good way to look at it is like this...

Say you have a smooth ball, and a ball not so smooth, and you put them in a big fish tank, and try spinning them. The smooth ball spins with minimum friction, while the not so smooth one creates little disruptions in the water. Now the surface of the second ball is disturbing the water around itself like if you stirred a pot of noodles. The imperfections on the surface of Earth "stir" the air and keep it "sectioned" with the help of mountain ranges and such. So, if you wonder why the earth just doesn't spin around at over 1,000 MPH under a plane, it's because the air is moving along the surface of the Earth in the same direction, and similarly to water, it casually tugs things within itself in the same direction.

The earth is a sphere. It spins around its axis. From the axis to the outside of the sphere is the "radius". The radius is longest in the middle of the sphere. From the middle to the top and bottom(poles) the radius gets smaller and smaller. If u measure the sphere in the middle u get the length of the equator. If u measure it at any point at a 90 degree angle to the axis u get the circumference. The radius and circumference are directly related to each other. Because the earth revolves around it's axis once every 24 hours the time is set however the radius and circumference are variables. The longer the circumference the more distance is travelled in these 24 hours and so we get the 1000 mph at the equator of 24000 miles. The closer you get to the poles the smaller the circumference which means that the speed at which u move along with the earth gets lower and lower untill u are at 0mph at the pole.

- the eotvos effect. if you weigh yourself while travelling east or west, your weight changes. You weight slightly less if you're travelling with the rotation of Earth. More if you're travelling against the rotation. The effect is strongest at the equator.
- Coriolis effects. air and ocean currents in the north and south swirl in opposite directions due to the Earths spin.

proof the Earth is not stationary.
- retrograde motion of planets. Can you learn how to use a telescope?
- earthquakes, tectonic plate motions, volcanos. Can you learn how to read a seizmometer?

proof it's round
- sunsets again. you can watch a sunset, go to the top floor of a skyscraper and watch the same sunset again 2-3 minutes later. This would be impossible if it was perspective. Can you use an elevator button and your own eyes?
- lunar eclipses. These would be impossible for the Earth to go between the moon and sun. Also the shape of Earth's shadow on the moon is ALWAYS round, no matter where the eclipse is visible. Only a sphere could do this.
- Endless supply of photos and videos. Not just talking about NASA. Talking about the thousands backyard hobbyist who strap cameras to rockets and balloons.
- long bridges need to take into account the curvature of the Earth.
- 24 hour light/dark in the antarctic circle during the summer/winter solstices.
- flight patterns. All flights paths arc slightly towards the north or south pole. Flights times and routes in the southern hemisphere in particular make no sense with the FE map. A flight from Australia to Argentina would be farther than the Jets fuel range.

To get fairly technical, there is another factor at play here. It's practically imperceptible, but I'm surprised +MinutePhysics didn't even talk about it.

The reason why rockets are launched towards east is because they use the rotation of the earth as an advantage. To create a stable orbit around the earth, we have to speed up perpendicularly to its center of mass, in order to counteract it's gravity. The more speed you have, the larger your orbit gets. Inversely, the slower you go, the more you will feel the effects of gravity and fall back to earth. So to summarize, a plane that ads up more perpendicular speed by going east (let say about 1100 mph) will be under less gravity pull than a plane going west (say 900 mph). In other words: it means it would use less fuel to fly, so we could use that extra fuel to go faster.

Technically, it'd be faster to fly East.

ACTUALLY, you are really faster when you are flying west, the reason was even called in the video:
The coriolis force.
And i do NOT mean the winds created by the coriolis force, even in a world completely without wind you are faster when flying west than east. You do not even have to fly. It is enough to jump upwards.

I know this because i am a physics student and had to calculate this effect last week.

The reason is the following:

Imagine you are standing on earth at Point P.
Because you contact P, you and P have the same velocity and the same angular velocity.
Now you jump upwards. Because you experience no force tangential to earth's surface, your velocity stays the same.
But because you moved upwards, you increased your radius to earth's axis.

Because Perimeter= 2*pi*r
, you also have to larger a bigger distance when rotating around the earth than Point P.

Because you have the same velocity as point P, but you have to travel a larger distance, Point P is moving away from you eastwards, with other words you are moving westwards relative to earth's surface.


This effect is TINY, because your jump height compared to earth's radius is tiny, but still measrable.
Using this effect, earth's angular velocity can be calculated ehrn you drop a stone from a known height and measure the deviation.

So in fact, it is really faster to Fly west. At least by 0,001% :)

It's all motion in a particular reference frame. If your frame of reference is in an orbit around the Sun so that your altitude above Earth is constant, and the Earth is spinning below you, as depicted in this video, that's exactly right. And that's the key, the reference frame. If your frame of reference is a fixed location on the Earth, it might make intuitive sense that you could travel faster going west, but as Henry points out, there are other factors, like the air rotating with the Earth, that counter those assumptions.
